name: Vitiligo
description: Vitiligo is a long-term skin condition in which patches of skin lose their pigment (color). The affected areas become white and usually have sharp margins. The hair from the skin may also become white.
symptoms: Premature whitening or graying of hair (scalp, eyelashes, eyebrows, beard)
Loss of color in tissues that line the inside of the mouth and nose (mucous membranes)

early_stage.description: Non-segmental vitiligo often starts with pale patches that gradually turn completely white. It may begin on hands, forearms, feet, or face.

middle_stage.description: Active Vitiligo: Patches enlarge and new patches appear. This can happen slowly over years or rapidly.

advanced_stage.description: Stable Vitiligo: The patches stop spreading and remain static. In severe cases (Vitiligo Universalis), nearly all skin pigment is lost.

causes: The exact cause is unknown, but it involves the destruction of melanocytes. Theories include autoimmune destruction, genetic oxidative stress imbalance, and neurogenic factors.

favorable_conditions.temperature: Sun exposure can cause burns on depigmented skin
favorable_conditions.environment: Physical or emotional stress, skin trauma (sunburn, cuts)

impact.prevalence: Affects 0.5% to 2% of the world population.
impact.socio_economic_impact: Primarily psychological distress, social stigmatization in some cultures, and costs for cosmetic/medical treatments.

diagnosis.field_diagnosis: Visual examination, Wood's lamp examination (UV light makes white patches glow).
diagnosis.laboratory_diagnosis: Skin biopsy (rare), Blood tests to check for other autoimmune conditions (thyroid, diabetes).

susceptible_populations: People with autoimmune diseases (Hashimoto's, Alopecia Areata), Family history.
life_cycle: Chronic and unpredictable. It may stop (stable), progress slowly, or spread rapidly (active).

dataset_metadata.intended_use: Machine learning training, research, and educational purpose
